content: What South African leader, who became the country's first black president in 1994, spent 27 years in prison for fighting against apartheid?

Ah, I think I know who you're talking about. It's Nelson Mandela, right? He was a really important figure in South Africa's history. He fought against apartheid, which was a system where the government separated people based on their race and gave different rights to different groups. It was really unfair and unjust.

Mandela spent 27 years in prison because of his activism against this system. He was seen as a threat to the apartheid regime because he was working to bring about equality and freedom for all South Africans, regardless of their race. His time in prison only served to make him more famous and respected around the world as a symbol of resistance against oppression.

Finally, in 1990, after international pressure and internal shifts in South Africa, Mandela was released from prison. He continued his work towards ending apartheid and in 1994, when South Africa held its first fully democratic elections, he was elected as the country's first black president.

His presidency was marked by efforts to reconcile the different racial groups in South Africa and to build a united nation. He passed away in 2013, but his legacy continues to inspire people all over the world who fight for justice and equality.
